article:
In macroeconomics, 'aggregate demand' ('AD') is the total demand for final goods
and services in the economy (Y) at a given time and price level.

 It is the amount of goods and services in the economy that will be
purchased at all possible price levels. {{cite book
  | last = O'Sullivan first = Arthur authorlink = Arthur O'Sullivan (economist)
  | coauthors = Steven M. Sheffrin title = Economics: Principles in action
  | publisher = Pearson Prentice Hall year = 2003 location = Upper Saddle River,
  | New Jersey 07458 pages = 307 url = http://www.pearsonschool.com/index.cfm?l-
  | ocator=PSZ3R9&PMDbSiteId=2781&PMDbSolutionId=6724&PMDbCategoryId=&PMDbProgr-
  | amId=12881&level=4
 oi =
  | id = isbn = 0-13-063085-3}} This is the demand for the gross domestic
  | product of a country when inventory levels are static. It is often called
  | effective demand, though at other times this term is distinguished.

It is often cited that the aggregate demand curve is downward sloping because at
lower price levels a greater quantity is demanded. While this is correct at the
microeconomic, single good level, at the aggregate level this is incorrect. The
aggregate demand curve is in fact downward sloping as a result of three distinct
effects: Pigou's wealth effect, the Keynes' interest rate effect and the Mundell-
Fleming exchange-rate effect.
